text_image_relationship.layout_style: Two columns of text divided by a central vine-scroll margin; a square miniature in the upper right column interrupts the text and is followed by a red rubric caption; a large ornamented initial in the middle of the right column; full borders filled with acanthus‐style vine scrolls and naturalistic birds; text flows above and below image elements, establishing a clear visual hierarchy: miniature > initial > marginalia.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, professional book hand with regular line-spacing, extensive use of abbreviations and red rubrics

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for key decorative fields (background grid and vine bezants); ultramarine used for architectural elements to convey status; alternating red and blue in garments to create rhythmic contrast; layered application with white lead highlights on blue surfaces; green on grass to anchor scene; original pigments well-preserved with minimal darkening

features: Two combatants placed centrally on a single ground line
Frontal castle façade grid behind figures
Architectural framing by castle and miniature frame
Symmetrical balance between left and right combatant

decorative_elements: Acid-etched vine scroll border with gold bezants
Naturalistic birds perched on vine terminals
Square architectural frame for miniature with red and gold bars
Ornamental initial with interlaced foliate motif and micro-architectural cusps

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill-pen outlines in brown ink with varying weight for contour and internal detailing
drawing_technique.shading_method: Flat color fields with minimal hatch—white lead highlights on blue robes and helmets
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling and overlapping; no vanishing-point perspective, depth implied by ground line and superimposition

content_theme.scene_description: A single full-page miniature: two fully armored knights joust before a checkered ultramarine-and-gold crenellated wall. The knight on the left wears a red surcoat over mail, his helm crested and visor raised; he charges with a white-and-red lance. The knight on the right, in a blue surcoat bearing a gold device, braces with a green-and-white striped lance. Both mounts are richly caparisoned (red-and-gold and blue-and-white), hooves planted on densely painted green grass. The castle background is rendered as a grid of arcaded bays, each alternating blue and gold, to convey fortified architecture. The composition rests on a single horizontal ground line. Secondary elements: the foliate border with birds frames the scene and echoes the decorative initial below. Symbolic components: shield devices identify noble lineages; the checkered wall may allude to a specific fortress. Compositional focus is on the crossing lances, with visual weight centered and supported by the strong architectural backdrop.

secular: Two noble knights in full armor and surcoats, bottom‐margin knights in dueling poses

architectural: Crenellated castle façade with painted arcades

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, smooth surface with fine pricking and ruling visible under magnification; regular quaternion gatherings, margins approx. 3 cm.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent; vivid pigments with minimal silvering or darkening; slight surface abrasion at margin corners; historic edge repairs to lower border stabilized.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in miniature
Regular plummet ruling for text alignment

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Noble patron’s private household, educated courtly readership

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This page, likely produced in a Parisian workshop c. 1400–1420, exemplifies the International Gothic style’s hallmark combination of sumptuous color and intricate marginal decoration. The use of ultramarine and burnished gold leaf indicates access to costly materials, suggesting a high-status commission. The central miniature’s depiction of a tournament or battle before a stylized castle grid reflects the contemporary courtly fascination with chivalric ideals and heraldic display. Surrounding vine-scrolls populated by birds and drolleries align with the Ornamental Style perfected in Paris at this date. The Gothic textura quadrata hand, precise ruling, and rubricated captions point to professional scribes collaborating with illuminators. Iconographically, the combat scene celebrates noble martial prowess and lineage, with shield devices serving as visual identifiers. Comparisons with the Bedford Hours and BnF Fr. 25526 reveal shared motifs—particularly the architectural framing and naturalistic marginalia—while this manuscript’s richer color saturation and heavier gold application suggest a slightly later, more opulent phase of production. Technically, XRF and IR reflectography uncover layered pigment application and confident underdrawing, marking an advanced workshop practice. Overall, this leaf bridges traditional narrative illumination with emerging aesthetic refinements of the early 15th century, offering insight into the social and artistic milieu of late medieval France.
